comment.text: This translation key is used to display an error message indicating that the surname entered is incorrect. It appears in a form field within a registration dialog and is triggered when an invalid last name is provided. The label "Incorrect last name" helps translators understand the specific context of the error message.

usage.context:
className="field"
 hasError={!isSurnameValid}
 errorMessage={
 lastName.trim().length === 0
 ? t("Common:RequiredField")
 : t("Common:IncorrectLastName")
 }
 >
 <TextInput
 className="last-name"
 scale

hasError={!snameValid}
 errorMessage={
 errorText ||
 (sname.trim().length === 0
 ? t("Common:RequiredField")
 : t("Common:IncorrectLastName"))
 }
 >
 <TextInput
 id="last-name"
 name="last-name"

ai_spell_check_issues.description: While "Ungültiger Nachname" is technically correct (invalid last name), "Falscher Nachname" might be a more natural and common translation for "Incorrect last name" in many contexts. "Ungültiger" often implies a system error or technical invalidity, whereas "falsch" simply means wrong.

The Japanese translation "姓が正しくありません" literally translates to "Last name is incorrect." While understandable, a more natural and nuanced translation might convey the intended meaning of 'Incorrect last name' more accurately depending on the context. It's a bit direct.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider alternatives like "名字が違っています" (Namae ga chigatteimasu - 'Family name is different') or "苗字が正しくありません" (Namaza ga seishiku arimasen - 'Given name/family name is not correct'). The best option depends on the overall tone and context of the application.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Korean translation "유효하지 않은 성입니다" (yu-hyo-ha-ji a-neun seong-im-ni-da) translates to 'Invalid last name'. While close, it doesn't perfectly capture the nuance of 'Incorrect last name'. 'Incorrect' implies a mistake, while 'Invalid' implies it's not acceptable. Depending on the context, a more appropriate translation might be something like '잘못된 성입니다' (jal-mot-deun seong-im-ni-da) which means 'Wrong last name'.
ai_spell_check_issues.suggestion: Consider '잘못된 성입니다' (jal-mot-deun seong-im-ni-da) for a more direct translation of 'Incorrect last name'.

ai_spell_check_issues.description: The Romanian translation 'Numele incorect' literally translates to 'The incorrect name'. The English phrase 'Incorrect last name' implies a specific part of the name is wrong, not the entire name. A more accurate translation would be 'Prenume greșit' or 'Nume de familie greșit'.

The Sinhala translation 'අග නම වැරදිය' while literally meaning 'last name is wrong,' doesn't convey the precise meaning of 'Incorrect last name' which implies an error was made. A more accurate translation would highlight the mistake.
The term 'last name' is typically translated as 'prezime' in Serbian (Cyrillic), not 'prezime'. While 'prezime' exists, 'prezime' is the more commonly used and accurate translation in this context.

The translation "Họ không đúng" while literally meaning 'They are not correct/right' doesn't accurately convey the meaning of "Incorrect last name." It focuses on the possessor rather than the last name itself.

While "姓氏不正确" is a literal translation, it's not the most natural or user-friendly phrasing for an error message. "Incorrect last name" often implies a mismatch or typo, and the Chinese translation doesn't fully capture this nuance. A more suitable translation would be something like "姓氏输入错误" (Last name input error) or "姓氏与记录不符" (Last name does not match the record).
